case_name: Mai v. James T. Vaughn Correctional Center et al
ocr_text:
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE DISTRICT OF DELAWARE

SIR CEA G. MAI,

aka Hermione Kelly Winter

aka Kelly E.S. Aliahmed

aka Evonca Sakinah S. Aliahmed
aka Kelly E. Sakinah

aka David Allen Allemandi,

Petitioner,
v. : Civil Action No. 20-1225-LPS

ATTORNEY GENERAL OF THE
STATE OF DELAWARE,

Respondents.

MEMORANDUM

1. BACKGROUND

On April 10, 2014, Petitioner pled guilty to second degree rape and continuous sexual abuse
of a child (as the lesser included offenses of first degree tape). See Winter v. May, 2020 WL 6743063,
at *1 (D. Del. Nov. 17, 2020). The Superior Court sentenced Petitioner as follows: (1) for the
continuous sexual abuse of a child conviction, twenty-five years of Level V incarceration (with credit
for 216 days previously served), suspended after five years for twenty years of Level III probation,
and (2) for the second degree rape conviction, twenty-five years at Level V, suspended after fifteen
yeats and successful completion of the Transitions Sex Offender Program for one year of Level IV
confinement, followed by eight years of Level III probation. See id. Petitioner did not appeal her
convictions or sentences.

In 2017, Petitioner filed a petition for federal habeas relief pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2254. See

id. The Coutt denied the petition in its entirety after determining that one claim lacked metit and

the remaining two claims were procedurally barred from federal habeas review. See id, at *3-9.
Petitioner did not appeal that decision to the Third Circuit.

Presently pending before the Court is Petitioner’s new petition for federal habeas telief
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2254 (“Petition”).
Il. LEGAL STANDARDS

A federal district court may summatily dismiss a habeas petition “if it plainly appeats from
the face of the petition and any exhibits annexed to it that the petitioner is not entitled to relief.”
Rule 4, 28 U.S.C. fol. § 2254. A district court can entertain a habeas petition “in behalf of a person
in custody pursuant to the judgment of a State court only on the ground that he is in custody in
violation of the Constitution or laws or treaties of the United States,” and only if the relief sought is
either immediate release or speedier release. See Preiser v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 475, 500 (1973).
Ill. DISCUSSION

‘The actual form petition filed by Petitioner does not contain any grounds challenging the
legality of her custody, and only states that she seeks “release from prison.” (D1. 1 at 15) Inan
“Affidavit” attached to the petition, Petitioner asserts general complaints about the conditions of her
confinement, concetns about her ill mother, and her own medical concerns. (D.I. 1-1 at 1) These
complaints do not present issues cognizable on federal habeas review, and are more propertly
asserted via 18 U.S.C. § 1983 (although they may also lack merit under that statute as well). Given
the number of § 1983 cases Petitioner has filed in this Coutt,' it would appear that Petitioner is
awate of the proper method for raising the instant issues. Accordingly, the Court will summarily

dismiss the instant Petition for lack of jurisdiction.

‘See, e.g, Aliabmed v. Mears, Civ. A. No. 21-219-LPS; Sakinah v. Carney, Civ. A. No. 20-1195-LPS.
2

I
i
1
|
IV. CONCLUSION

For the reasons set forth above, the Court will summarily dismiss the instant Petition. The
Court will also decline to issue a certificate of appealability because Petitioner has failed to make a
“substantial showing of the denial of a constitutional right.” See 28 U.S.C. § 2253(c)(2); 3d Cir.

LAR. 22.2 (2011); United States v. Eyer, 113 F.3d 470 (3d Cir. 1997). A separate Order will be

entered,
Wilmington, Delaware HONORABLE LEONARD P. STARK
June 13, 2022 UNITED STATES CIRCUIT JUDGE

IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE DISTRICT OF DELAWARE

SIR CEA G. MAI,

aka Hermione Kelly Winter

aka Kelly E.S. Aliahmed

aka Evonca Sakinah S. Aliahmed
aka Kelly E. Sakinah

aka David Allen Allemandi,

Petitioner,
v. : Civil Action No. 20-1225-LPS

ATTORNEY GENERAL OF THE
STATE OF DELAWARE

Respondents.

ORDER
At Wilmington, this 13th day of June, 2022, for the reasons set forth in the Memorandum
issued this date;
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that:
1. Petitioner Sir Cea G. Mai’s Petition for Habeas Corpus Relief Under 28 U.S.C. §
2254 (D.I. 1) is SUMMARILY DISMISSED.
2. The Court declines to issue a cettificate of appealability because Petitioner has

failed to satisfy the standards set forth in 28 U.S.C. § 2253(c)(2).

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
